document.docAuthor: Nattier, Romain, Jourdan, Hervé, Mille, Christian & Chazeau, Jean
document.masterDocTitle: An annotated checklist of the Coccinellidae (Coleoptera) from New Caledonia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: An annotated checklist of the Coccinellidae (Coleoptera) from New Caledonia

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Coccinella bicruciata
Montrouzier, 1861
: 304
(pars)—synonymized by
Fauvel 1903
: 328
.
Alesia frenata :
Masters 1888
: 90
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
This species was misidentified as
Coelophora bicruciata
by
Montrouzier ( 1861 )
. According to
Fauvel ( 1903 )
, who examined the type series of
Coelophora bicruciata ,
it was a mixture of
Coelophora inaequalis
and
Micraspis frenata
specimens. This species is common in Australasia ( Australia , Tasmania and Papua New Guinea ). Iablokoff-
Khnzorian ( 1982 )
treated the species as a junior synonym of
Micraspis lineata (
Thunberg, 1781
)
. This
Micraspis
is very common over New Caledonia , mostly from open areas on the west coast, but also the Central Range, Isle of Pines, and Belep Islands (Art Island ). Its trophic preferences are wide, being mostly a hemipteran predator (aphids, cicadellids, psyllids), but it is able to eat pollen or extrafloral nectaries when prey are scarce (
Hawkeswood & Turner 2002
;
Lundgren 2009
). It has been widely recorded in close association with the invasive psyllid,
Heteropsylla cubana
, in New Caledonia (
Gatimel 2005
). This species has not yet been widely promoted for biocontrol, despite high potential in agroecosystems (
Chenaux et al. 2011
).
